case: A 54-year-old Black with a history of aortic stenosis and travel to South America presents with subacute progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, a cough that produces pink sputum, orthopnea, and unintentional weight loss. They are found to be febrile, hypoxemic, tachypneic, and tachycardic.
differential: Heart Failure exacerbation secondary to Aortic Stenosis
Malaria (if recent travel to endemic area)

case: A 54-year-old Black with a history of aortic stenosis and travel to South America presents with subacute progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, a cough that produces pink sputum, orthopnea, and unintentional weight loss. They are found to be febrile, hypoxemic, tachypneic, and tachycardic.
differential: Heart Failure exacerbation secondary to Aortic Stenosis
Malaria (if recent travel to endemic area)

case: A 54-year-old Black with a history of aortic stenosis and travel to South America presents with subacute progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, a cough that produces pink sputum, orthopnea, and unintentional weight loss. They are found to be febrile, hypoxemic, tachypneic, and tachycardic.
differential: Heart Failure exacerbation secondary to Aortic Stenosis
Pneumonia (bacterial or fungal, possibly related to travel history)
Chagas Disease (Trypanosoma cruzi infection, related to South American travel)
Lung Cancer (with possible metastasis or paraneoplastic syndrome)
Malaria (with pulmonary involvement, related to travel history)

differential: Heart Failure exacerbation due to Aortic Stenosis
